Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Australia
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Jocelyn M. Lavallee of Colorado State University to conduct a research project in Biological Sciences during the summer of 2013 at James Cook University in Cairns, Australia. The project title is "Measuring the Turnover of Black Carbon in Soil Using Hydrogen Pyrolysis." The host scientist is Dr. Michael I. Bird.

Black carbon, also known as charcoal or pyrogenic carbon, is broadly defined as the carbon-rich residue left after incomplete combustion of fossil fuels and biomass. It is commonly found in soils, and there is evidence that it turns over very slowly (over hundreds of years to millennia). Incorporation of carbon into charcoal may be an important mechanism of carbon stabilization in soils, but little is known about what factors control its turnover. This project uses a promising new technique called hydrogen pyrolysis to study charcoal carbon in soils. Hydrogen pyrolysis is combined with elemental analysis and mass spectrometry to measure the carbon abundance and isotopic signature of charcoal, which is used to calculate turnover times. The aim is to relate the turnover time of charcoal carbon to environmental variables such as climate, dominant vegetation, and management.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, this investigation will encourage teaching and integration of diversity through mentoring an undergraduate student from James Cook University. The investigators will recruit a student from an under-represented group who is interested in pursuing a degree and/or career in science through the Student Mentor Program, designed to encourage under-represented students from specific equity groups. At the culmination of the project, this student will be encouraged to join a laboratory group at James Cook University and to pursue his or her own research project. This Fellow will also gain experience in working with scientists of different nationalities, and in forming lasting collaborations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Charcoal, also known as black carbon or pyrogenic carbon, is broadly defined as the carbon-rich residue left after incomplete combustion of fossil fuels and biomass. It is commonly found in soils, and there is evidence that it turns over very slowly (over hundreds of years to millennia). Incorporation of carbon into charcoal may be an important mechanism of carbon sequestration in soils, and charcoal has been shown to provide several ecosystem services, including improved soil fertility, soil hydrology, and water quality. Despite charcoal’s important contribution to multiple ecosystem services, we know very little about what factors control its stability in soils. It is imperative that we improve our understanding of charcoal dynamics so that we can better predict its behavior and use it more effectively to provide ecosystem services.

 

For this project, I used a promising new technique called hydrogen pyrolysis to study charcoal carbon in soils. I combined hydrogen pyrolysis with elemental analysis and mass spectrometry to measure the carbon abundance and isotopic signature of charcoal, which I am using to calculate the turnover time of that carbon. During my stay at James Cook University, I pyrolyzed over 150 soil samples from three agricultural sites, each with two or three management treatments. Prior to pyrolysis, whole soils were separated into four different fractions according to size and density. The four fractions were: 1) light fraction, consisting of all material less dense than 1.85g/cm3); 2) particulate organic matter, which is >53 micrometers in size; 3) silt, which is 2-53 micrometers in size; and 4) clay, which is <2 micrometers in size. The light fraction, and the particulate organic matter fraction contain organic matter that has short turnover times because it is readily available to microbes. Conversely, the silt and clay fractions contain mineral-bound carbon, which turns over slowly because it is protected from decomposition. Previous results confirm that total carbon in these fractions turns over at different rates, and we want to know whether charcoal carbon in these fractions also turns over at different rates. We also want to know whether agricultural management, i.e. cultivation and tillage, affects these rates of turnover.

 

Initial results suggest that charcoal carbon is most stable when associated with clay-sized soil particles. Little to no charcoal larger than 53 micrometers was found in any of the soils, suggesting that charcoal of this size is quickly broken down to a smaller size or lost from the system. Further data analysis and integration of charcoal turnover times into an organic matter decomposition model are ongoing. Once these tasks are complete, we will have an understanding of how the charcoal dynamics are affected by cultivation and tillage, and how that contributes to the broader cycling of organic matter in agricultural soils.
